name: Joshua Graham
descriptions: Joshua Graham, also known as the Burned Man and formerly known as the Malpais Legate, is a Mormon missionary from the settlement of New Canaan and a co-founder of Caesar's Legion as well as its first legate. After three decades of service in the Legion, helping Caesar carry out his conquest of the former state of Arizona and much of the former American Southwest, Graham's strategic loss in 2277 to the New California Republic at the First Battle of Hoover Dam resulted in Caesar punishing him by being set on fire and thrown into the Grand Canyon, only to survive. When Caesar retaliated by sending the White Legs raiders to raze New Canaan and chase the survivors into Zion Canyon in 2281, Graham rallied the Dead Horses tribe as their war-chief to protect Zion and atone for his bloodstained past.
He appears as the central character in the Fallout: New Vegas add-on Honest Hearts and is mentioned in Fallout: New Vegas and its add-on Lonesome Road.

Born in New Canaan, a Mormon community established in what remained of the city of Ogden, Utah, Joshua Graham grew up in peaceful times, learning the trade of a missionary and an interpreter due to his natural aptitude for languages. In 2246, Graham received the call to partake in his sacred service to spread the good word to the people of the wasteland. By the time he left his home, he was already fluent in several tribal dialects. His aptitude for linguistics made him a natural choice when the Followers of the Apocalypse asked for assistance in their expedition to the Grand Canyon. Graham departed New Canaan, following the Long 15 and US Route 89 south towards Arizona to meet two Followers, Bill Calhoun and Edward Sallow on the way, joining their expedition to provide assistance to the local tribes residing in and around the Grand Canyon, and to make a study of their dialects, with Graham providing translations between both groups.

Around 2247, the Blackfoot tribe were their first stop in the Grand Canyon. Though Joshua proved to be a capable interpreter, the hospitality of their hosts was abruptly replaced with hostility. Whether it was an error in translation that Joshua made, or some unrelated misunderstanding, the Blackfoots switched to holding the entire expedition for ransom.
The Legate rallies his legionaries

With his teachings and Graham's skills, the Blackfoots prevailed over the other tribes and hailed Sallow as their leader. Graham became a field commander, training the forces of the fledgling army and leading them in battle. His leadership position soon entailed retaliatory raids and terrorizing local tribes. When Sallow cast off his old name and crowned himself Caesar, lord of the Legion, Graham became the first legate, the 'Malpais Legate'. For thirty years he helped Caesar conquer the tribes residing in the former American Southwest, taking over large swaths of the former states of Utah, Colorado, Arizona, and New Mexico, strengthening the Legion with every tribe assimilated. Though Graham admits that he was neither a particularly brilliant strategist nor tactically flexible, his menace and brutality as the Malpais Legate were infamous. The atrocities he committed under Caesar's banner made him feared by friend and foe alike. A dangerous, unpredictable, destructive force above all else, Graham was legendary for being impossible to kill, surviving multiple assassination attempts by First Recon sharpshooters and NCR Rangers.
Despite his infamous reputation, there comes an end to everything eventually. For the Malpais Legate, his end came at the First Battle of Hoover Dam.

Left to carry the shame of his failure at Hoover Dam, the Malpais Legate returned to Caesar back east. But the Son of Mars' anger would not accept the Legion's loss in battle. To demonstrate to the remainder of his army that failure would not be tolerated, even from the highest ranks, Caesar brought Graham back to the Grand Canyon. Caesar ordered his Praetorian Guard to cover the legate in pitch, set him on fire and throw him from the cliff's edge, to be left for dead in the canyon below.
The birth of the Burned Man

Despite the clear lethality that such a punishment carried, Graham's legendary toughness allowed him to survive the descent. Waking up the following day, burned and broken, but alive, the fallen legate realized he had nowhere to go but home, back to New Canaan. Under the extreme pain of his injuries, Graham crawled out of the northern edge of the Grand Canyon and began the long trek back. After his fiery descent, Graham's attempts to dull the pain of his burns led him to discover he possessed a natural immunity to wasteland drugs, both positive and negative, leaving him with only replacing the bandages covering his charred skin each day to prevent infection; the process forces him to expose his flesh to the air and he comments that it feels like being burned alive all over again.

Meanwhile, the terror of the Malpais Legate and the story of his blazing fall into the Grand Canyon coalesced into legends of the fearsome "Burned Man" stalking the wastelands, spreading among the remaining tribes until eventually reaching the ears of Caesar. Realizing that his attempt to punish Graham had failed, Caesar forbade his legionaries from speaking Graham's true name under threat of death (the practice of Damnatio memoriae), but this only served to enhance the menace of the Burned Man.
For his part, Graham decided to forgive Caesar's actions in their shared history, in keeping with his religious belief that one must hate the sin, but love the sinner.
Joshua Graham making his way to New Canaan after killing several assassins of Caesar's Legion

By 2281, Graham's bloodstained past finally caught up with him. The White Legs, whipped into a frenzy and equipped by Ulysses on Caesar's orders, staged an attack on New Canaan while Joshua and most of the capable Canaanites was away from the city, in a bid to ingratiate themselves with the Legion by destroying Graham's family tribe, and Graham, along with them. Most of the Mormon tribe was slaughtered and the survivors scattered into the wilderness, with the bulk of them seeking refuge in Zion Canyon. In order to defend them and the tribes that made their home in the canyon, Graham assumed the position of acting war chief among the Dead Horses, a tribe he had interacted with during his time with the Legion, alongside Daniel, another missionary and survivor from New Canaan, who joined up with the Sorrows.

When the White Legs pursued them into Zion, Daniel and Graham found themselves in a conflict with each other: while Daniel would rather use peaceful delaying action to allow the Sorrows and Dead Horses to safely evacuate Zion and lose the White Legs in the wilderness, Joshua desired nothing more than to bring God's justice to those who would bring senseless harm to others, and wipe the White Legs from the face of the earth. The impulse to exact vengeance on those who butchered his people, killing all who could not run away fast enough - the elderly, the ill, children, and even those who stopped to help - burns within him alongside his guilt for past sins and desire for true repentance.
Joshua Graham inspecting .45 Auto pistols for use against the White Legs

Joshua Graham is at heart a conflicted man. Originally a follower of the Mormon faith, he steadily betrayed everything he held dear in service to Caesar, helping the warlord conquer the tribes of the wasteland.

Despite his former allegiance to Caesar's Legion and its brutal way of life, the Burned Man does not hold any ill will towards the NCR and its allies. To him, the NCR is still redeemable in his eyes, believing it was the greed of man that led to the Great War, and that only through faith in God and prayer and genuine acts of kindness, can humanity hope to prevent history from repeating itself. Conversely, he has a dim opinion of Mr. House, viewing the lord of New Vegas as another Caesar: a man who brought the tribes to heel and wields his power for the domination of others.

His hatred towards the Legion stems not just from the act of being burned alive by Caesar, but also the combination of Caesar's belief that his will alone is enough to unite the wasteland under the Legion's banner and his refusal to let anything stop him. Ultimately, though, his greatest enmity lies in one person: Joshua Graham - for letting himself get swept up in the bloodshed that heralded Caesar's rise to power, for falling in line as his Legate, and for willfully perpetuating the innumerable atrocities that helped establish the Legion's rule in the wasteland. What he thought was the start of a community of equals under one banner had become the heinous regime of a tyrant, and it was something Joshua earnestly believed he would spend the rest of his life atoning for.

Joshua Graham appears in the Fallout: New Vegas add-on Honest Hearts and Fallout: Wasteland Warfare as "The Burned Man" unit. He is mentioned in Fallout: New Vegas and its add-ons Dead Money and Lonesome Road. He was also intended to appear in Van Buren, the canceled Fallout 3 by Black Isle Studios.

It's not as simple as being "set on fire". After suffering a terrible failure, he was humiliated by his superior and the people he commanded. He was cast out and left for dead. His entire reason for living was gone. When your entire way of life is completely destroyed, it has a profound impact on how you view yourself and your place in the world. Because all momentum is lost, the experience causes you to evaluate and re-evaluate how you have reached this point -- and how to move forward.

As much as can be expected. A lot of players really wanted to see the Hanged Man/Burned Man incarnation from the Van Buren design documents, so I think most of those people were unhappy with how he turned out.

I had wanted to develop a religious conflict in an RPG for a while, one that wasn't presented as pro-religion vs. anti-religion. I didn't want to use a proxy/fictitious religion and I didn't want to use religion as the set-up for a series of jokes. My first idea for Honest Hearts was a direct conflict between Joshua and Daniel where Joshua was more like his pre-fall self, but I didn't think the characterization would be particularly interesting and I didn't think players would struggle much with the decision of whom to support. It didn't take long for me to change the main conflict to one about Joshua and Daniel vs. an external threat, with the player's choice revolving around which leader to support. I think we often present players with a choice between two bad solutions and we ask them to decide which one is least bad. With Honest Hearts, I wanted the player to decide which solution would produce the most good.

I wanted the player's first encounter with Joshua to be very reductive. In way, I wanted the player to be initially disappointed. They hear legends of this fearsome, terrible, demonic figure and when they first see him, he's doing the equivalent of putting his pants on one leg at a time: sitting at a table maintaining a stack of guns. Even internally, some people complained about his appearance. They wanted him to be huge and monstrous or they wanted his first encounter with the player to involve him brutally gunning down White Legs. I believed that for his character to feel right in the context of the story, he needed to be a man first and the monster later. But that expressed desire on the team made me ask for the graffiti players see on the way to see Joshua: an entire cliff face dominated by the image of Joshua with tiny White Leg corpses falling down below him. In the image, he's like Goya's Saturn, dwarfing and destroying everyone around him.

Presenting the conflict with Daniel posed some challenges because Daniel is not a living legend, i.e. he is even more of a normal man than Joshua is trying to be. Additionally, Mormonism is not a pacifistic religion (and its soteriology does not depend on pacifism), so the conflict could not reasonably by framed around violence vs. non-violence even in the post-apocalyptic version followed by the New Canaanites. Daniel's concern was about larger issues than fighting or not-fighting; he was concerned that Joshua's lapsed nature would cause a whirlwind of warfare that would pull everyone far away New Canaanite traditions to the point where religion was virtually abandoned in favor of a war cult surrounding Joshua.
Subconsciously, yes, but I didn't sit down and think "gonna make this dude a Greek tragic hero".

I think it's worth noting that in even Van Buren's documents, a lot of the references to the Hanged Man's "evil" refers to past acts. In VB, he was seemingly a man without purpose. While his characterization by others and his tendency to laugh off/ignore attempts by others to control him could have been interesting, it really ended at "nasty guy who says and does creepy stuff and is a badass". There were specific instances (such as at New Canaan) where he would specifically avoid conflict and showed some additional depth, but he effectively had no character arc within the story.

Personally, I think the "wow so crazy" type characters aren't particularly interesting or insightful because they only exist in pure fantasy and, as such, can't really be related to. I think it's important for characters who are influencing player opinions to be more-or-less human. If you can't put yourself in the character's shoes, it's hard to empathize with him or her.

topics.topic_text: FollowersAcknowledgeMyOrder
topics.response_text: Yes, of course.

topics.topic_text: It's time for us to part ways.
topics.response_text: {quietly}Ha ha ha. I don't think so.

topics.topic_text: On second thought, stick with me for a little longer.
topics.response_text: Good, because I wasn't going to leave.

topics.topic_text: Yes, I'm sure.
topics.response_text: I'm not going anywhere. Get the idea out of your head and get moving.

topics.topic_text: I think we should travel together.
topics.response_text: The path lies before us. Let's not waste any time.

topics.topic_text: FollowersStealthing
topics.response_text: {a li'l sinister, drawn out, quiet}Yes.

topics.topic_text: Let's talk about your tactics.
topics.response_text: What have you to teach me of tactics?

topics.topic_text: I want you to change your combat style.
topics.response_text: Oh?

topics.topic_text: I want you to attack enemies the moment you see them.
topics.response_text: {"of course"}It's the only way I know.

topics.topic_text: That's it for your tactics. Let's talk about something else.
topics.response_text: Anything else?

topics.topic_text: That's all. Let's get going.
topics.response_text: All right.

topics.topic_text: Switch to a melee weapon.
topics.response_text: Fine. If that's your style, I can adapt.

topics.topic_text: I want you not to attack enemies unless I've already engaged them.
topics.response_text: {a bit irritated}What's the point?

topics.topic_text: I want you to use ranged weapons.
topics.response_text: Naturally.

topics.topic_text: Let's talk about how close you're following me.
topics.response_text: Whatever you'd like. It makes no difference to me.

topics.topic_text: Stay close to me.
topics.response_text: I'm at your side.

topics.topic_text: Your distance is good. Let's talk about something else.
topics.response_text: Anything else?

topics.topic_text: All right, you're good. Let's get out of here.
topics.response_text: After you.

topics.topic_text: Keep your distance. Try to flank them.
topics.response_text: As you like.

topics.topic_text: Enough about tactics.
topics.response_text: Anything else?

topics.topic_text: Let's trade equipment.
topics.response_text: No thanks.

topics.topic_text: Wait here.
topics.response_text: Sorry. That's not going to happen.

topics.topic_text: GREETING
topics.response_text: This is taking too long. We can't let Salt-Upon-Wounds escape. I'm going to find a way around. God willing, we will finish this together.

topics.topic_text: I've met Caesar, you know. What do you think he would say if I told him you were here?
topics.response_text: I think that would put him - and you - in a difficult position. Caesar has agents looking for me, but he won't admit I'm alive.

topics.topic_text: I have some gear that needs repairs.
topics.response_text: Let me have a look. My tribe may take too much pride in its mechanical talents, but in truth we are intrigued by the workings of a fine firearm.

topics.topic_text: Wait, Joshua! Don't!
topics.response_text: [FAILED] No! He and his tribe have worked hard for their wages. Who am I to deny them?

topics.topic_text: Let's do it.
topics.response_text: God be with you.

topics.topic_text: I came here with the Happy Trails Caravan Company to make contact with the New Canaanites.
topics.response_text: Happy Trails.{quietly remembering}I remember.{small smile}They were good friends.

topics.topic_text: Joshua, you've already won. Look around you. There's no need to kill him.
topics.response_text: [SUCCEEDED] He has a debt to pay for what he's done and I've come to collect. And so he's chosen to cower in the water like a dumb animal.

topics.topic_text: Let him keep his dignity. Give him a fighting chance.
topics.response_text: He never had any dignity to begin with. None of them did.

topics.topic_text: No objections.
topics.response_text: {flat}God's will.

topics.topic_text: How do I get out of here?
topics.response_text: Even though you made your way in, there's no easy way back. Without a map, you'll die in the wilderness.

topics.topic_text: Pray? God? What are you talking about?
topics.response_text: I am a New Canaanite. We believe we are the heirs of a spiritual tradition given to our ancestors thousands of years ago.

topics.topic_text: Nice guns.
topics.response_text: In the Great Basin and Colorado Plateau, all tribes are known for a specific weapon.

topics.topic_text: I'm not going to leave without offering to help. What can I do?
topics.response_text: {referring to the parable of the good samaritan}You're a good neighbor to us. We all go through periods of darkness. In such times, we can turn to the Lord, but it's good to have friends.

topics.topic_text: Don't try to get me to help you. I'm not interested.
topics.response_text: There are only so many ways you could have entered Zion from the south. You descended by routes that you cannot safely ascend to return to the Mojave.

topics.topic_text: How about I go find dear Daniel and shake the information out of him?
topics.response_text: There are many reasons why that would be a bad idea. I will illuminate three.

topics.topic_text: Why don't you or Daniel do it?
topics.response_text: We are responsible for leading and protecting the Sorrows and Dead Horses. They are smart people, but not as worldly as you or I.

topics.topic_text: Taboo?
topics.response_text: The Sorrows believe in a spirit that lives in the caves, say the spirit punished them once for trespassing.

topics.topic_text: I'll see what I can do.
topics.response_text: Thank you. Follows-Chalk can help you find your way around the valley.

topics.topic_text: Sorry, but I'm not going on a scavenger hunt for you.
topics.response_text: The choice is yours, of course, but you're not going to find a way back to the Mojave without our help.

topics.topic_text: I'll see you on the other side.
topics.response_text: Go with God, brother.

topics.topic_text: Follows-Chalk seems like he's interested in seeing more of the world.
topics.response_text: I thought he might. It's been some time since I've visited...{emph}civilized places. I don't have fond memories of them.

topics.topic_text: Well, I'm guessing you're pretty mad about something.
topics.response_text: The White Legs didn't just force my people out of New Canaan. They butchered everyone who wasn't fast enough to get away.

topics.topic_text: All right, let's go.
topics.response_text: Right.

topics.topic_text: No, and I don't really care.
topics.response_text: Living in willful ignorance is an ugly thing, but God often speaks loudest in the wild places of his creation, like Zion.

topics.topic_text: You don't want to leave Zion. You'd rather kill every last one of the White Legs.
topics.response_text: Given those two choices, yes. In the best of all possible worlds, they would just leave us in peace. But they won't.

topics.topic_text: This conversation just got pretty dark. What was that about happy... dashing the little ones?
topics.response_text: Happy are those who do the work of the Lord. Zion belongs to God and the people of God. It is a natural temple and monument to his glory.

topics.topic_text: Why are you talking to me about it?
topics.response_text: Daniel and I don't agree on everything, but in our hearts, we both want what's best for the Sorrows and Dead Horses.

topics.topic_text: You'll get no argument from me. These White Legs are human garbage.
topics.response_text: They're still God's children, but if they turn against their brothers and sisters, won't listen to reason...

topics.topic_text: I'll talk to him about it. Maybe he can be persuaded.
topics.response_text: Thank you. It will be for the best.

topics.topic_text: I need to think about it.
topics.response_text: Of course. Think on it, and look in your heart. The light of the mind alone cannot dispel the whole world's darkness.

topics.topic_text: Yes, what has to be done is you have to get these tribes out of here.
topics.response_text: The Sorrows need help. We brought the White Legs here, the New Canaanites. This is their home, Zion, God's gift to them.

topics.topic_text: And what kind of tribe is that?
topics.response_text: God told Moses that the tribes of Cain would not be welcome in Zion. The White Legs are as close as I have seen, beyond hope, beyond redemption.

topics.topic_text: I do. They're little more than raiders, if that.
topics.response_text: Then you must bear witness of this revelation to Daniel. The obviousness of it escapes him.

topics.topic_text: Fair enough, I guess.
topics.response_text: I and the Dead Horses are prepared to do what must be done to protect Zion from the White Legs.

topics.topic_text: Hmm. Okay.
topics.response_text: You're not so certain. Fair enough. We all have doubts.

topics.topic_text: I don't know if you've figured this out yet, but I don't believe what you believe.
topics.response_text: Then as a Gentile, you should find this to be even more beneficial. If the Sorrows stay in Zion, you will always have a link to New Canaan.

topics.topic_text: Fair enough. What do you want me to do about it?
topics.response_text: Talk to Daniel about fighting the White Legs. He wants to evacuate the valley, believes it is best for the Sorrows, physically and spiritually.

topics.topic_text: Enough with the drama. I just want to get home.
topics.response_text: I understand. The safest way for you to resolve this is to help me and the Dead Horses defeat the White Legs.

topics.topic_text: Do you run the show around here?
topics.response_text: I wouldn't say that. I am the acting war chief for the Dead Horses. They look up to me for such matters, but I only have the authority they give me.

topics.topic_text: What's going on with all of these... tribes?
topics.response_text: A great deal. There are three, make that four, tribes here in Zion. You've already met the White Legs on the way in.

topics.topic_text: Sounds like a good deal.
topics.response_text: In a world filled with misery and uncertainty, it is a great comfort to know that, in the end, there is light in the darkness.

topics.topic_text: Huh. If you say so.
topics.response_text: Whether there is a God or not, his existence doesn't depend on what you believe or what I say.

topics.topic_text: Ha ha ha! Wait... you don't actually believe that, do you?
topics.response_text: I know it may be hard for you to accept or even to understand. In my heart, I believe that though I am a sinner, I have been saved.

topics.topic_text: Do you ever "fall?"
topics.response_text: Every day. Some days are... harder than others.

topics.topic_text: Why did the White Legs attack my caravan?
topics.response_text: They attack everyone who isn't a White Leg, especially caravans. They don't know how to survive on their own, so they have to raid.

topics.topic_text: Does the valley belong to the Dead Horses?
topics.response_text: The valley belongs to God, but no. The Dead Horses live at Dead Horse Point, up the Colorado River. They came here because I asked them to.

topics.topic_text: Why haven't I seen any Sorrows in the valley?
topics.response_text: The Sorrows have many skilled hunters among them, but no warriors. They have not had to deal with war or raiders for decades.

topics.topic_text: Are the New Canaanites really a tribe?
topics.response_text: We wear more clothing than them and understand more about technology, but we're still a tribe, a linked family of families.

topics.topic_text: Thanks for the offer, but I'll handle it myself.
topics.response_text: I don't think so.

topics.topic_text: What do you know of Salt-Upon-Wounds?
topics.response_text: He's a butcher. Believe me, I know the godless fire that burns in his heart. I've been burned by it myself.

topics.topic_text: Do they speak... our language?
topics.response_text: Most don't. It's been hundreds of years since the war. They've developed their own languages.

topics.topic_text: Let's talk about something else.
topics.response_text: Of course.

topics.topic_text: Do you have anything to trade?
topics.response_text: We do. Though the White Legs destroyed New Canaan, they didn't destroy all of our supply caches.

topics.topic_text: Goodbye.
topics.response_text: God be with you.

topics.topic_text: Can I ask you some personal questions?
topics.response_text: Right now, I'd like you to focus on helping Daniel. Maybe there will be time later.

topics.topic_text: Were you always with the New Canaanites?
topics.response_text: I was born in Ogden, what people came to call New Canaan. Things were more peaceful when I was growing up.

topics.topic_text: If what you believe is true, he'll pay for it later. The Sorrows don't need to see you do this.
topics.response_text: {initial anger}I want to take from them what they took from me, from my family.{becoming sad}In this life. I want them to suffer. I want all of them to die in fear and pain.

topics.topic_text: What are those bandages for?
topics.response_text: [FAILED]{irritated}For injuries I suffered long ago.

topics.topic_text: Who are you to decide this?
topics.response_text: [FAILED] I am the right hand of the Lord and the instrument of his vengeance!

topics.topic_text: Was one of those men Caesar?
topics.response_text: No, not then. Back then he was just Edward. Smart man. Young, but we all were. We thought we could hike into the Grand Canyon and talk to Blackfoots.

topics.topic_text: How did you end up as Caesar's legate?
topics.response_text: This way lies the path to hell. Edw- Caesar needed me to translate. Translation became giving orders. Giving orders became leading in battle.

topics.topic_text: How did you survive?
topics.response_text: I survived because the fire inside burned brighter than the fire around me. I fell down into that dark chasm, but the flame burned on and on.

topics.topic_text: Are you in much pain? Is there anything I can do to help?
topics.response_text: [SUCCEEDED] You are kind to offer, but no, there's nothing you can do. We don't use chems, but I learned long ago that I'm immune to their effects.

topics.topic_text: What do you know about the war between Caesar and NCR?
topics.response_text: I try not to involve myself with matters of the Mojave anymore. All I know is from before the Battle of Hoover Dam.

topics.topic_text: What do you think of NCR?
topics.response_text: Better than Caesar, but that's not a high standard. Too much love of money and ownership, not enough love of God and giving.

topics.topic_text: You know that means I'm going to encourage him to leave, right?
topics.response_text: Follows-Chalk needs more guidance in his life. Just not from me.

topics.topic_text: Do you know about Mr. House?
topics.response_text: I had heard of him, but when we were preparing to enter the Mojave, he didn't seem relevant to what was happening.

topics.topic_text: I'm guessing you don't like Caesar very much.
topics.response_text: Love the sinner, hate the sin. With Caesar, it's often very difficult to see through all of that sin to the person inside.

topics.topic_text: What's at the Divide?
topics.response_text: I don't know for certain, and I don't think NCR knows, either. Whatever happened at the Divide was too much for them to handle.

topics.topic_text: The Divide blocked all of their northern land routes?
topics.response_text: Not all of them. But they couldn't take 127 north to get around the mountains.

topics.topic_text: Hmm. Okay.
topics.response_text: Whatever you tell him, I'm sure it will be fine.

topics.topic_text: Fine by me. I prefer the wilderness.
topics.response_text: Then let him know. Follows-Chalk needs more guidance in his life. I'd prefer it not come from me.

topics.topic_text: What did you say about a courier? Who were you expecting?
topics.response_text: Caesar would never admit this openly, but he knows that I'm alive. I've killed enough of his frumentarii and assassins that have come looking.

topics.topic_text: Caesar is dead. I saw to it personally. I thought you should know.
topics.response_text: {pause}I have to admit, it's hard to believe. That even after all he did to me, all he{emph}tried to do to find and erase me from this world, he went first.

topics.topic_text: They won't. I'll make sure the Legion has very little to go home with.
topics.response_text: Hmm. Good. You're doing God's work, whether you believe it or not.

topics.topic_text: We'll see.
topics.response_text: The Lord shall reveal all things in good time.

topics.topic_text: You don't think Lanius can lead the Legion?
topics.response_text: I think only Caesar can lead the Legion. I've never met anyone who could take his place. I couldn't. I never had a mind for logistics.

topics.topic_text: How do you know so much about what happened to me?
topics.response_text: The Dead Horses are capable scouts. Nothing passes into or out of Zion without my hearing of it.

topics.topic_text: NVDLC02EndingJoshuaGraham
topics.response_text: {Narration - Joshua died}After a long and troubled life, Joshua Graham finally found rest in Zion.

topics.topic_text: NVDLC02JoshuaAboutZion
topics.response_text: By the rivers of Babylon, there we sat down, yea, we wept, when we remembered Zion.

topics.topic_text: < NVDLC02MQ04 Finale Force Greet >
topics.response_text: Don't listen to this... thing! His cries are those of a mad beast caught in a thicket! He gave no mercy to my family, and I will give none to his.

topics.topic_text: < NVDLC02MQ04 Intro Force Greet >
topics.response_text: Thank you for this. I know Daniel doesn't approve, but destroying the White Legs is the only way to ensure the Sorrows can remain in Zion.

topics.topic_text: < Joshua Graham tells the player he's looking for another way to SUW. >
topics.response_text: This is taking too long. We can't let Salt-Upon-Wounds escape. I'm going to find a way around. God willing, we will finish this together.

topics.topic_text: NVDLC02JoshuaMQ4SUWFinished
topics.response_text: There. That's it. It's finished. When they hear what happened here, the White Legs will crawl back to their Great Salt Lake.

topics.topic_text: PLAYER IN IRON SITES
topics.response_text: You're not the first to have tried.

topics.topic_text: PLAYER LAY MINE
topics.response_text: Be careful. Tribals don't always recognize those for what they are.

topics.topic_text: PLAYER THROW GRENADE
topics.response_text: Frag out!

conversation.response_text: We warned you at Syracuse, and you persisted.

combat.response_text: That sort of thing might be seen as a dumb prank in the Mojave, but it will get you killed out here.
There will be time to grieve later.
We're a tolerant community, but don't overstep the limits of our generosity.
